faq.title: Plagiarism checker FAQ
faq.subtitle: Frequently asked questions about use, results, and reliability.

item-1.question: How do I use VeriIA‚Äôs plagiarism checker?
item-1.answer: Paste your text, upload a supported file, or paste a URL, click ‚ÄúCheck plagiarism‚Äù, and in seconds you‚Äôll get a report with a match percentage, detected sources, and passages that deserve a closer look.

item-2.question: Which file types and formats can I scan?
item-2.answer: You can scan pasted text, .doc/.docx/.pdf/.txt files, and public URLs. For the clearest report, keep formatting simple.

item-3.question: How many words can I scan and how do credits work?
item-3.answer: Each word you scan with the plagiarism checker costs 2 credits. The total cost depends on the length of your text, so it‚Äôs good to check your balance before you start a large scan.

item-4.question: What happens to my documents and data?
item-4.answer: Your texts are only used to generate the plagiarism checker report; we don‚Äôt train models on them, and you can delete your scan history whenever you like.

item-5.question: What exactly counts as plagiarism?
item-5.answer: Plagiarism means presenting someone else‚Äôs content as your own without clear citation ‚Äî copying, translating, or paraphrasing others‚Äô words or ideas without proper credit.

item-6.question: Does a high percentage mean I‚Äôm definitely plagiarizing?
item-6.answer: Not always. There may be valid citations, common phrases, or standard definitions. You should review each match and decide whether it needs a citation or a rewrite.

item-7.question: Do citations or the bibliography show up as matches?
item-7.answer: Yes. Plagiarism checkers flag textual overlap ‚Äî citations, references, or common phrases often show up; you simply need to confirm they‚Äôre properly cited or slightly rewrite them.

item-8.question: Can paraphrasing be marked as plagiarism?
item-8.answer: Yes. If you keep the same structure or ideas without citing the source, even if you change some words, it can still be considered plagiarism.

item-9.question: Can I plagiarize myself (self-plagiarism)?
item-9.answer: Yes. Reusing substantial parts of your previous work without declaring it can be treated as self-plagiarism in academic or publishing contexts.

item-10.question: How can I reduce the match percentage?
item-10.answer: Identify the highlighted sections, add citations where needed, rewrite in your own words, and then run another scan with the plagiarism checker to confirm the text is original enough.

faq.title: Word counter FAQ
faq.subtitle: Understand how the word counter works and how it treats your text.

item-1.question: Is VeriIA‚Äôs word counter really free?
item-1.answer: Yes. VeriIA‚Äôs word counter is a free tool: you can paste your text and see words, characters, and reading time without creating an account or spending credits.

item-2.question: Does my text get sent to VeriIA‚Äôs servers when I use the word counter?
item-2.answer: No. The word counter runs directly in your browser: your text is processed locally and is not stored or sent to our servers.

item-3.question: What does the word counter measure besides word count?
item-3.answer: In addition to words, VeriIA‚Äôs word counter shows characters with and without spaces, the number of sentences and paragraphs, and an approximate reading time in minutes.

item-4.question: Why does the word counter show a different number than Word or Google Docs?
item-4.answer: Because each tool uses slightly different rules to define a ‚Äúword‚Äù. Some counters include numbers, URLs, or certain formatted elements and others don‚Äôt, so small differences are normal.

item-5.question: What counts as a ‚Äúword‚Äù in an online word counter?
item-5.answer: Typically, a word is any group of characters separated by spaces or punctuation. Numbers, hashtags, or links can be counted as a single word depending on the word counter.

item-6.question: How can I estimate how many pages X words will be?
item-6.answer: First, use the word counter to get the total word count. As a rough guide, 250‚Äì300 words is about one page double-spaced at 12 pt, and around 500 words is one single-spaced page.

item-7.question: How is reading time calculated in the word counter?
item-7.answer: The word counter estimates reading time by dividing the total number of words by an average reading speed, for example 200‚Äì250 words per minute. It helps you see if an article or newsletter is longer than your audience expects.

item-8.question: Does the word counter work well with any language?
item-8.answer: It works best with languages that separate words using spaces, like English or Spanish. In texts with many symbols or in languages without clear spaces, there can be small variations.

item-9.question: Is there a practical length limit for using the online word counter?
item-9.answer: In practice, the limit is set by your browser and available memory. For very long manuscripts, it‚Äôs usually easier to split the content into sections and run each part through the word counter.

item-10.question: When does it make sense to use an online word counter instead of Word or Google Docs?
item-10.answer: When you want a quick check without opening a document, when you work across many formats, or when you need extra metrics like reading time. It‚Äôs an extra layer of control on top of your regular editor.

faq.title: Text compare FAQ
faq.subtitle: Quick answers before you use the text compare tool.

item-1.question: Is VeriIA‚Äôs text compare tool free, and do I need an account?
item-1.answer: VeriIA‚Äôs text compare tool is free to use: you can paste two versions, compare them, and see changes without spending credits or creating an account.

item-2.question: Which formats does the text compare tool support?
item-2.answer: The text compare tool is optimized for pasted text and plain text files like .txt or .md. We recommend simple formatting so highlights stay clean and easy to read.

item-3.question: Where are my texts processed when I use text compare?
item-3.answer: The diff for text compare runs in your browser: we don‚Äôt need to upload your texts to a server to calculate differences.

item-4.question: What kinds of differences does a text compare tool show?
item-4.answer: A text compare tool usually shows what was added, what was removed, and what changed between two versions, often at line, word, or character level.

item-5.question: Why can two text compare tools show different results for the same documents?
item-5.answer: Because each text compare tool uses different rules and algorithms. Some compare by line, others by words or characters, and some can ignore spaces or capitalization depending on settings.

item-6.question: Can I use the text compare tool for code as well?
item-6.answer: Yes, many people use text compare for code. It helps you see which lines were added, removed, or modified between two versions of a file, although it doesn‚Äôt analyze syntax.

item-7.question: Is there a practical size limit for online text compare?
item-7.answer: Online text compare tools work best with moderately sized documents. For very long texts, it‚Äôs usually better to split them into sections and compare each part separately.

item-8.question: Can I use text compare to detect plagiarism?
item-8.answer: Text compare is great for seeing differences between two known versions, but it doesn‚Äôt search the whole web. For plagiarism checks, it‚Äôs better to use a dedicated plagiarism checker alongside text compare.

item-9.question: Is it safe to use text compare with sensitive documents?
item-9.answer: It depends on how each tool handles your data. A text compare tool that runs entirely in the browser, like VeriIA‚Äôs, is safer because your text doesn‚Äôt leave your device.

item-10.question: What best practices do you recommend when using text compare?
item-10.answer: Paste as plain text, use the same text compare tool across a project, enable options like ignoring spaces when you only care about content changes, and keep simple summaries of diffs to document what changed.

faqs.title: Frequently asked questions
faqs.subtitle: Clear answers about how we detect AI

item-1.question: What is this AI detector and what can it analyze?
item-1.answer: The VeriIA AI detector estimates how likely it is that a text was written with models like ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, DeepSeek or Kimi. It works for research papers, blog posts, professional reports, long emails‚Äîany kind of professional writing.

item-2.question: How does the AI detector work in broad strokes?
item-2.answer: The AI detector analyzes structure, rhythm, repetition, and word choice and compares them against human and AI examples. It then outputs a global probability and highlights sections worth reviewing. It evaluates style, not isolated words.

item-3.question: How accurate is the AI detector? Can it be wrong?
item-3.answer: It is probabilistic, not an absolute verdict. In most cases the AI detector is a useful signal, but false positives and false negatives can happen. Use it as one input among others, not as the only decision maker.

item-4.question: How should I read the percentage and highlights?
item-4.answer: The percentage shows how much the overall text resembles AI writing. It does not mean that exact percent of the text is AI. Highlights point to sentences or paragraphs with more AI-like style so you can review them more carefully.

item-5.question: What is the minimum length and which file formats are supported?
item-5.answer: We recommend at least 30‚Äì50 words for more stable AI detector results. You can paste text or upload .docx and plain text formats like .txt. Very short fragments are less reliable for any detector.

item-6.question: Which languages does the AI detector support right now?
item-6.answer: The AI detector is currently optimized for Spanish and English. We will add more languages when we can guarantee reasonable detection quality.

item-7.question: Is there a free plan for the AI detector? What are the limits?
item-7.answer: Yes. You can use the AI detector for free with a limited number of checks. To analyze more texts or unlock advanced features, our paid plans raise the limits.

item-8.question: What happens to my texts? Do you store or train on them?
item-8.answer: We do not permanently store your texts or use them to train our models or third-party models. We only process the content to generate the AI detector report and do not share it with other tools.

item-9.question: Does the AI detector work with mixed or paraphrased texts?
item-9.answer: Yes. The AI detector can analyze texts with both human and AI parts, or paraphrased drafts. The result reflects the overall style‚Äîthe more you edit and personalize, the further it moves away from typical AI patterns.

item-10.question: What if I am sure my text is original but the AI detector flags it as AI?
item-10.answer: Remember that the AI detector gives an estimate, not a legal verdict. Keep drafts, notes, and edit history as evidence of your process. Use the report as a starting point for discussions with teachers, clients, or reviewers, not as a substitute for human judgment.
